noun.definition: A person who behaves badly or in a way that breaks the law.

adjective.definition: (of a person) behaving badly or in a way that breaks a law or rule.
adjective.example: her miscreant husband

noun.definition: A person who dislikes, despises, or is strongly prejudiced against women.

adjective.definition: Relating to or characteristic of a misogynist.
adjective.example: a misogynist attitude

verb.definition: Make less severe, serious, or painful.
verb.example: he wanted to mitigate misery in the world

noun.definition: A device such as a pattern of letters, ideas, or associations that assists in remembering something.
noun.example: the usual mnemonic for star types is O Be A Fine Girl Kiss Me

adjective.definition: Aiding or designed to aid the memory.

noun.definition: A small quantity of a particular thing, especially something considered desirable or valuable.
noun.example: his statement had more than a modicum of truth

verb.definition: Appease the anger or anxiety of (someone)
verb.example: nature reserves were set up around the power stations to mollify local conservationists

meaning: solid and uniform; constituing a single; unified whole;

adjective.definition: Formed of a single large block of stone.
(of an organization or system) large, powerful, and intractably indivisible and uniform.
adjective.example: rejecting any move toward a monolithic European superstate

adjective.definition: (of a solid-state circuit) composed of active and passive components formed in a single chip.
Sullen and ill-tempered.
adjective.example: she was morose and silent when she got home

meaning: many colored; made up of many parts

adjective.definition: Incongruously varied in appearance or character; disparate.
adjective.example: a motley crew of discontents and zealots

noun.definition: An incongruous mixture.
noun.example: a motley of interacting interest groups

noun.definition: The particolored costume of a jester.
noun.example: life-size mannequins in full motley

adjective.definition: Many and of various types.
adjective.example: multifarious activities

meaning: worldy as opposed to spiritual; concerned with the ordinary

adjective.definition: Lacking interest or excitement; dull.
adjective.example: seeking a way out of his mundane, humdrum existence

adjective.definition: Of this earthly world rather than a heavenly or spiritual one.
adjective.example: the boundaries of the mundane world

noun.definition: The supposed practice of communicating with the dead, especially in order to predict the future.
noun.example: alchemy, necromancy, and other magic practices

verb.definition: Nullify; make ineffective.
verb.example: alcohol negates the effects of the drug

verb.definition: Make (a clause, sentence, or proposition) negative in meaning.
Deny the existence of (something)
verb.example: negating the political nature of education

noun.definition: A newly coined word or expression.
A person who is new to a subject, skill, or belief.
noun.example: four-day cooking classes are offered to neophytes and experts

meaning: a means of connection; a center

noun.definition: A connection or series of connections linking two or more things.
noun.example: the nexus between industry and political power

adjective.definition: (of a person) surprised and confused so much that they are unsure how to react.
adjective.example: he would be completely nonplussed and embarrassed at the idea

adjective.definition: (of a person) not disconcerted; unperturbed.

meaning: sentimental longing for a past time

noun.definition: A sentimental longing or wistful affection for the past, typically for a period or place with happy personal associations.
noun.example: I was overcome with acute nostalgia for my days in college

meaning: medicine or remedy of doubtful effectiveness

noun.definition: A medicine, especially one that is not considered effective, prepared by an unqualified person.
noun.example: a charlatan who sells nostrums

adjective.definition: Of no value or importance.
adjective.example: a nugatory and pointless observation

adjective.definition: Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action.
adjective.example: I argued this point with him, but he was obdurate

adjective.definition: Obedient or attentive to an excessive or servile degree.
adjective.example: they were served by obsequious waiters

meaning: to make unnecessary; to anticipate and prevent

verb.definition: Remove (a need or difficulty)
verb.example: the Venetian blinds obviated the need for curtains

verb.definition: Stop, close up, or obstruct (an opening, orifice, or passage)
verb.example: thick makeup can occlude the pores

verb.definition: (of a tooth) close on or come into contact with another tooth in the opposite jaw.
(of a solid) absorb and retain (a gas or impurity).

meaning: relating to practices connected with supernatural phenomena

noun.definition: Supernatural, mystical, or magical beliefs, practices, or phenomena.
noun.example: a secret society to study alchemy and the occult

adjective.definition: Of, involving, or relating to supernatural, mystical, or magical powers or phenomena.
adjective.example: a follower of occult practices similar to voodoo

adjective.definition: (of a disease or process) not accompanied by readily discernible signs or symptoms.

verb.definition: Cut off from view by interposing something.
verb.example: a wooden screen designed to occult the competitors

meaning: a long; adventurous voyage; a quest;

proper noun.definition: A Greek epic poem traditionally ascribed to Homer, describing the travels of Odysseus during his ten years of wandering after the fall of Troy. He eventually returned home to Ithaca and killed the suitors who had plagued his wife Penelope during his absence.

adjective.definition: Assertive of authority in an annoyingly domineering way, especially with regard to petty or trivial matters.
adjective.example: the security people were very officious

adjective.definition: Relating to the sense of smell.
adjective.example: the olfactory organs

meaning: form of government in which power belongs to only a few leaders

noun.definition: A small group of people having control of a country, organization, or institution.
noun.example: the ruling oligarchy of military men around the president

adjective.definition: (of a task, duty, or responsibility) involving an amount of effort and difficulty that is oppressively burdensome.
adjective.example: he found his duties increasingly onerous

meaning: formation or use of words that imitate sounds of the actions they refer to

noun.definition: A person who studies or is an expert on birds.

verb.definition: Move or swing back and forth at a regular speed.
verb.example: a pendulum oscillates about its lowest point

verb.definition: Vary in magnitude or position in a regular manner around a central point.

adjective.definition: Characterized by vulgar or pretentious display; designed to impress or attract notice.
adjective.example: books that people buy and display ostentatiously but never actually finish

adjective.definition: Showing excessive confidence or pride.
adjective.example: overweening ambition

meaning: song of joy or triumph; a fervent expression of joy

noun.definition: A song of praise or triumph.

meaning: study of past geological eras through fossil remains

adjective.definition: (of a person's face) pale, typically because of poor health.

meaning: elaborate praise; formal hymn of praise

noun.definition: A public speech or published text in praise of someone or something.
noun.example: Vera's panegyric on friendship

noun.definition: A person or thing regarded as a perfect example of a particular quality.
noun.example: it would have taken a paragon of virtue not to feel viciously jealous

meaning: one-sided; committed to a party; group or cause;

noun.definition: A strong supporter of a party, cause, or person.
A member of an armed group formed to fight secretly against an occupying force, in particular one operating in enemy-occupied Yugoslavia, Italy, and parts of eastern Europe in World War II.

adjective.definition: Prejudiced in favor of a particular cause.
adjective.example: newspapers have become increasingly partisan

adjective.definition: Relating to pathology.
adjective.example: the interpretation of pathological studies

noun.definition: The dialect of the common people of a region, differing in various respects from the standard language of the rest of the country.
noun.example: the nurse talked to me in a patois that even Italians would have had difficulty in understanding

noun.definition: The presence of something only in small or insufficient quantities or amounts; scarcity.
noun.example: a paucity of information

adjective.definition: Of or like a pedant.
adjective.example: many of the essays are long, dense, and too pedantic to hold great appeal

adjective.definition: Translucently clear.
adjective.example: mountains reflected in the pellucid waters

meaning: superficial; performed really as a duty
point in an orbit that is closest to the earth
to disturb greatly; make uneasy or anxious
anything that is restored after suffering great destruction

noun.definition: A person's facial features or expression, especially when regarded as indicative of character or ethnic origin.
The quality of being religious or reverent.
noun.example: acts of piety and charity

adjective.definition: Having a pleasantly sharp taste or appetizing flavor.
adjective.example: a piquant tartare sauce

noun.definition: Stiff fabric, typically cotton, woven in a strongly ribbed or raised pattern.
noun.example: a white cotton piqué shirt

noun.definition: A feeling of irritation or resentment resulting from a slight, especially to one's pride.
noun.example: he left in a fit of pique

verb.definition: Stimulate (interest or curiosity)
verb.example: you have piqued my curiosity about the man

verb.definition: Feel irritated or resentful.
verb.example: she was piqued by his curtness

verb.definition: Pride oneself.

noun.definition: (in piquet) the scoring of 30 points on declarations and play before one's opponent scores anything.

verb.definition: Score a pique against (one's opponent).
Make (someone) less angry or hostile.
verb.example: they attempted to placate the students with promises

adjective.definition: (of a person or animal) not easily upset or excited.
adjective.example: this horse has a placid nature

adjective.definition: Sounding sad and mournful.
adjective.example: a plaintive cry

meaning: pliability; condition of being able to be shaped or formed

noun.definition: The quality of being easily shaped or molded.
A remark or statement, especially one with a moral content, that has been used too often to be interesting or thoughtful.
noun.example: she began uttering liberal platitudes

adjective.definition: (of love or friendship) intimate and affectionate but not sexual.
adjective.example: their relationship is purely platonic

adjective.definition: Of or associated with the Greek philosopher Plato or his ideas.
adjective.example: readers of the Platonic dialogues

adjective.definition: Confined to words, theories, or ideals, and not leading to practical action.
adjective.example: a Platonic gesture

noun.definition: A large or excessive amount of (something)
noun.example: a plethora of committees and subcommittees

noun.definition: An excess of a bodily fluid, particularly blood.

meaning: to examine deeply; determine the depth

verb.definition: Measure (the depth of a body of water).
Test (an upright surface) to determine the vertical.

noun.definition: A plumb bob.

adverb.example: a bassoonist who sits plumb in the middle of the wind section
drapery fell from their human forms plumb down

adjective.definition: Vertical.
adjective.example: ensure that the baseboard is straight and plumb

verb.definition: Install and connect water and drainage pipes in (a building or room)
verb.example: the house could not be plumbed at all

verb.definition: Fall or drop straight down at high speed.
verb.example: a climber was killed when he plummeted 300 feet down an icy gully

noun.definition: A steep and rapid fall or drop.
A plumb or plumb line.
Government by the wealthy.
noun.example: the attack on the Bank of England was a gesture against the very symbol of plutocracy

meaning: full of holes; permeable to liquids

adjective.definition: (of a rock or other material) having minute spaces or holes through which liquid or air may pass.

meaning: poerson who affects an attitude to impress others

noun.definition: another term for poser

adjective.definition: Dealing with things sensibly and realistically in a way that is based on practical rather than theoretical considerations.
adjective.example: a pragmatic approach to politics

verb.definition: Talk foolishly or at tedious length about something.
verb.example: I heard him prate on for at least an hour and a half

verb.definition: Talk at length in a foolish or inconsequential way.
verb.example: she began to prattle on about her visit to the dentist

noun.definition: Foolish or inconsequential talk.
noun.example: do you intend to keep up this childish prattle?

noun.definition: A preliminary or preparatory statement; an introduction.
noun.example: what she said was by way of a preamble

adjective.definition: Not securely held or in position; dangerously likely to fall or collapse.
adjective.example: a precarious ladder

noun.definition: A general rule intended to regulate behavior or thought.
noun.example: the legal precept of being innocent until proven guilty

noun.definition: A writ or warrant.
noun.example: the Commissioner issued precepts requiring the companies to provide information

meaning: to cause to happen; throw down from a height

verb.definition: Cause (an event or situation, typically one that is bad or undesirable) to happen suddenly, unexpectedly, or prematurely.
verb.example: the incident precipitated a political crisis

verb.definition: Cause (a substance) to be deposited in solid form from a solution.

adjective.definition: Done, made, or acting suddenly or without careful consideration.
adjective.example: I must apologize for my staff—their actions were precipitate

noun.definition: A substance precipitated from a solution.

meaning: rash; hasty; sudden; done without deliberation

verb.definition: Cause (an event or situation, typically one that is bad or undesirable) to happen suddenly, unexpectedly, or prematurely.
verb.example: the incident precipitated a political crisis

verb.definition: Cause (a substance) to be deposited in solid form from a solution.

adjective.definition: Done, made, or acting suddenly or without careful consideration.
adjective.example: I must apologize for my staff—their actions were precipitate

noun.definition: A substance precipitated from a solution.
A person or thing that comes before another of the same kind; a forerunner.
noun.example: a three-stringed precursor of the violin

verb.definition: Take action in order to prevent (an anticipated event) from happening; forestall.
verb.example: the government preempted a coup attempt

verb.definition: Acquire or appropriate (something) in advance.
verb.example: many tables were already preempted by family parties

verb.definition: Make a preemptive bid.

noun.definition: A preemptive bid.

adjective.definition: (chiefly of an animal's limb or tail) capable of grasping.
adjective.example: many monkeys have long, prehensile tails which they use in swinging through the trees

noun.definition: A strong feeling that something is about to happen, especially something unpleasant.
noun.example: he had a premonition of imminent disaster

verb.definition: (of an event) be a sign or warning that (something, typically something bad) will happen.
verb.example: the outcome of the game presaged the coming year

noun.definition: A sign or warning that something, typically something bad, will happen; an omen or portent.
noun.example: the fever was a somber presage of his final illness

adjective.definition: (of a person or their behavior) failing to observe the limits of what is permitted or appropriate.
adjective.example: I hope I won't be considered presumptuous if I offer some advice

meaning: supernatural; beyond the normal use of nature

adjective.definition: Beyond what is normal or natural.
adjective.example: autumn had arrived with preternatural speed

verb.definition: Speak or act in an evasive way.
verb.example: he seemed to prevaricate when journalists asked pointed questions

adjective.definition: Existing at or from the beginning of time; primeval.
adjective.example: the primordial oceans

adjective.definition: In its original condition; unspoiled.
adjective.example: pristine copies of an early magazine

noun.definition: The quality of having strong moral principles; honesty and decency.
noun.example: financial probity

adjective.definition: Constituting or presenting a problem or difficulty.
adjective.example: the situation was problematic for teachers

noun.definition: A thing that constitutes a problem or difficulty.
noun.example: the problematics of artificial intelligence

adjective.definition: Spending money or resources freely and recklessly; wastefully extravagant.
adjective.example: prodigal habits die hard

adjective.definition: Having or giving something on a lavish scale.
adjective.example: the dessert was crunchy with brown sugar and prodigal with whipped cream

noun.definition: A person who spends money in a recklessly extravagant way.

adjective.definition: (of a state, quality, or emotion) very great or intense.
adjective.example: profound feelings of disquiet

adjective.definition: (of a person or statement) having or showing great knowledge or insight.
adjective.example: a profound philosopher

adjective.definition: At, from, or extending to a great depth; very deep.
adjective.example: he opened the door with a profound bow

noun.definition: The vast depth of the ocean or of the mind.
